Row.Civilopedia: Scouts form the eyes and ears of early civilizations. These fleet-footed warriors are not supposed to engage with enemy forces - they're supposed to find the lay of the land, discovering any potential threats or treasures. A civilization that doesn't know what's going on in the world around it is blind to both peril and opportunity.
Row.Strategy: Just like the Scout, the Explorer can move through difficult terrain without penalty. It is very fast and efficient at exploring, but rather weak as well.
Row.Help: Much faster and stronger than the Scout, the mounted Explorer is the perfect tool to discover the world for your civilization. Receives +2 Sight while embarked.

Row.Civilopedia: In times when weapons were dull and military strategy was virtually non-existent, muscle power was the main tool of winning a fight. Especially strong and big men made good front-line warriors, who often fought in reckless rage. Nearly unstoppable when attacking, the Berserk fighters often did not watch their backs and were susceptible to strategic attacks.
Row.Strategy: The Savage is particularly useful when attacking enemy settlements. Armed with half a tree as weapon, he can easily bring down enemy fortifications.[NEWLINE]Protect it from attacks, as it is weak when defending.
Row.Help: An exceptionally big and strong human specimen with a bad temper.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Receives a bonus when attacking Cities, but also a penalty when defending.

Row.Text: Use your primate Alpha to support other units or strike hard and early.
An Alpha Leader is slightly stronger and better than the typical unit it represents. It also provides to other units around them.

Autochthons are the ancient ancestors of modern man. They learned to walk upright and this opened a whole new world to them. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]They were a hunter-gatherer people who used their minds and technology to create simple tools that aided them in their daily activities. Slowly, they achieved the ability to control fire creating a cascading effect that would eventually enlarge their brains, and their intelligence. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]This paleolithic man evolved over the course of two million years, eventually learning to create more complex tools allowing him to build better bows, more efficient carvings tools, and thus better dwellings. All this lead to an establishment of society and division of responsiblities. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With an increase in productivity there was an explosion in population and easier migrations. Man was starting to dominate the world...

Autochthons aren't much good at anything, but they have no maintenance. They have low offense and defense and will not be much of a match against anyone or anything else. They can be used to explore the nearby area but need to be careful against barbarian units. Taking on settlements is not recommended.
Very weak (but cheap) early unit. Lacking in offense and defense except in forests. +25% [ICON_COMBAT] Offense and +50% [ICON_DEFENSE] defense in forests.
Use the protector to guard your settlements as he gives you bonuses withing your settlement limits.
THe Protectors of the tribes take it upon themselves to understand how to best protect their village. They have bonuses giving them advantages in this area.
The Watcher is the first sentinel unit. Use him along your civilization's outskirts to alert you of danger.
A Watcher is a sentinal unit, providing you with the typical sentinel bonsues. A watcher will have the advantage of great visiion but is weak in combat and slow in movement.
Use the Runner to leap into battle, having a small chance of escaping. Weaker, but the scape bonus cold help.
A Runner is used to perform hit-and-run attacks. Due to it's weak combat, a single Runner may not be an effective combatant, but a group of runners could quickly take out dangerous oponents.
Use the bushman as your primitve advanced force. They are keen with their surroundings and typically won't need support of their settlements.
The early and primitive bushman takes advantage of the environment and is a powerful foe as an avanced guard. Mutli-talented, he can do well on his own.
With limited range and a very weak attach, the only real benefit is preventing immediate retaliation.
The Rock Thrower is the earliest ranged unit with only a one-tile range. This means getting up close, but at least there is no instant retaliation.

When man started walking upright and using the most basic tools he realized that some of these tools were not only helpful for self sustenance, hunting, and bettering his life, but could also be used as weapons that were more effective than simple brawling and biting. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Throwing rocks and hurling them with other tools, like slings, were effective but not as accurate as the first bow. [NEWLINE]The first bows had equivalent range as their sling counterparts, but had more points of lethal contact. It was also easier to establish competency, although it did take longer to make. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]These first projectile weapons gave man a much greater range of threat both in hunting and in combat. Raids on other groups could now be started and supported with bows from the perimiter. The first bows now gave man the ability to hide in brush without having to expose himself as with the sling. It was also much more lethal throwing rocks.

Primitive Archers are very weak in offense and especially defense. They should be next to another unit to attack since they can easily be overwhelmed in melee. This is still a small advantage since they will typically not receive retaliation damage and therefore should be used a support unit with other melee units.
A weak early ranged unit, using the most primitive of bows. Cheap and self-sufficient.
Wanderers learned to move quicker and have a higher curiousity. Use them to explore early on.
A wanderer unit has better movement that his early counterparts. He is very weak, so be careful.

After the discovery of Fire as a beneficial tool for cooking and surviving harsh winters, Man also found out about its destructive power. Fire was - and still is - a powerful element that can burn skin and turn buildings to cinders. For millennia, armies have made use of torches and burning projectiles of all sizes against their enemies.
A useful unit for all purposes, the Shaman is the second ranged unit in the Prehistoric Era. Use it to burn down cities or attack enemies, but protect it from melee attacks.
Prehistoric ranged unit, throws burning torches at the enemy. Has a short range.

The Axe Thrower is a Classical era range unit wich is an alternative to Composite Bowman. It has a better combat strength and have a free promotion that increase his defense against ranged attack, but has only 1 starting range (can increase with promotions). His promotion choices is those of range units.
Excellent early game unit for Tundra, Hills, and Mountains. Weak in desert.
The Neandertahal receives a 15% [ICON_COMBAT] offensive bonus while in Tundra, Hills, or Mountains. Also suffers a 10% defensive bonus in deserts.

In the earliest times of humanity, the Homo Sapiens Sapiens often used to live in caves, which provided shelter and protection before the invention of hut and house building. Armed with rudimentary weapons, like clubs or stones, they fought small battles between communities, or amongst themselves.
Take club, use club on enemy's head. All a Caveman needs to know.
A weak military unit.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Not very smart, but determined.

Improves [ICON_FOOD] Food [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_GOLD] Gold by constructing Improvements on map tiles outside of Cities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Cheap to train, but works slower than the Worker. May only construct very basic Improvements.
